title-group.article-title: Counting People with Low Incomes: the Impact of Recent Changes in Official Statistics

p.mixed-citation: See Nolan (1989) for an evaluation of this criticism.
A 'child' was any under 16 year old or any under 19 year old in non-advanced further education.
For a fuller discussion see DSS(1988c) or Nolan (op.cit.)

The official version of our Table 1 is Table CI in the HBAI analysis and is reproduced for reference in the Appendix. Nowhere does our reproduction differ by more than one percentage point from the corresponding figure in Table CI. Consequently we are confident that the general conclusions produced by our model are broadly in line with those which would be produced using the official methodology. Remaining discrepancies arise from differences in the uprating of income from self-employment and the imputation of income from sub-letting.

In its reply to a request by the Social Services committee to produce our Table 1 on a family or benefit unit basis (Q6, HMSO (1989), the DSS replied that this information 'could only be provided at disproportionate cost'. This seems a surprising response given that once household level tables have been created, all the hard work of setting up data, grouping individuals into benefit units etc. has already been done.

From these tables we cannot however say anything about the distribution of incomes within any of these groups. Where there are major changes in the within-group distribution this can make interpretation of the figures very difficult, and we hope to return to this issue in a future paper.
This was of course the normal income of the family unit rather than the household, but in this section we analyse only the effects of the change from normal to current income.
